texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: systemd
texts.text: systemd

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: NOTE: This works in Fedora 21, but not in Fedora 22. Review  this post  for the fixes.
texts.text: NOTE: This works in Fedora 21, but not in Fedora 22. Review  this post  for the fixes.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: GNOME 3  has improved by leaps and bounds since its original release and it's my daily driver window manager on my Linux laptop. Even with all of these improvements, there's still no built-in way to rotate wallpaper (that I've found).
texts.text: GNOME 3  has improved by leaps and bounds since its original release and it's my daily driver window manager on my Linux laptop. Even with all of these improvements, there's still no built-in way to rotate wallpaper (that I've found).

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There are some extensions, like  BackSlide , that enable background rotation on a time interval. Fedora 21 uses GNOME 3.14 and the current BackSlide version is incompatible. BackSlide's interface is fairly useful but I wanted something different.
texts.text: There are some extensions, like  BackSlide , that enable background rotation on a time interval. Fedora 21 uses GNOME 3.14 and the current BackSlide version is incompatible. BackSlide's interface is fairly useful but I wanted something different.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: One of systemd's handy features is the ability to set up  systemd  unit files on a per-user basis. Every user can create unit files in their home directory and tell systemd to begin using those.
texts.text: One of systemd's handy features is the ability to set up  systemd  unit files on a per-user basis. Every user can create unit files in their home directory and tell systemd to begin using those.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Getting started
texts.text: Getting started

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: We first need a script that can rotate the background based on files in a particular directory. All of my wallpaper images are in
texts.text: We first need a script that can rotate the background based on files in a particular directory. All of my wallpaper images are in

texts.label: code
texts.orig: ~/Pictures/wallpapers
texts.text: ~/Pictures/wallpapers

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: . I adjusted this script that I found on GitHub so that it searches through files in my wallpaper directory and picks one at random to use:
texts.text: . I adjusted this script that I found on GitHub so that it searches through files in my wallpaper directory and picks one at random to use:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
#!/bin/bash

walls_dir=$HOME/Pictures/Wallpapers
selection=$(find $walls_dir -type f -name "*.jpg" -o -name "*.png" | shuf -n1)
gsettings set org.gnome.desktop.background picture-uri "file://$selection"
texts.text:
#!/bin/bash

walls_dir=$HOME/Pictures/Wallpapers
selection=$(find $walls_dir -type f -name "*.jpg" -o -name "*.png" | shuf -n1)
gsettings set org.gnome.desktop.background picture-uri "file://$selection"

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I tossed this script into
texts.text: I tossed this script into

texts.label: code
texts.orig: ~/bin/rotate_bg.sh
texts.text: ~/bin/rotate_bg.sh

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: and made it executable with
texts.text: and made it executable with

texts.label: code
texts.orig: chmod +x ~/bin/rotate_bg.sh
texts.text: chmod +x ~/bin/rotate_bg.sh

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: . Before you go any further, run the script manually in a terminal to verify that your background rotates to another image.
texts.text: . Before you go any further, run the script manually in a terminal to verify that your background rotates to another image.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Preparing the systemd service unit file
texts.text: Preparing the systemd service unit file

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You'll need to create a user-level systemd service file directory if it doesn't exist already:
texts.text: You'll need to create a user-level systemd service file directory if it doesn't exist already:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: mkdir ~/.config/systemd/user/
texts.text: mkdir ~/.config/systemd/user/

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Drop this file into
texts.text: Drop this file into

texts.label: code
texts.orig: ~/.config/systemd/user/gnome-background-change.service
texts.text: ~/.config/systemd/user/gnome-background-change.service

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
[Unit]
Description=Rotate GNOME background

[Service]
Type=oneshot
Environment=DISPLAY=:0
ExecStart=/usr/bin/bash /home/[USERNAME]/bin/rotate_bg.sh

[Install]
WantedBy=basic.target
texts.text:
[Unit]
Description=Rotate GNOME background

[Service]
Type=oneshot
Environment=DISPLAY=:0
ExecStart=/usr/bin/bash /home/[USERNAME]/bin/rotate_bg.sh

[Install]
WantedBy=basic.target

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This unit file tells systemd that we have a oneshot script that will exit when it's finished. In addition, we also give the environment details to systemd so that it's aware of our existing X session.
texts.text: This unit file tells systemd that we have a oneshot script that will exit when it's finished. In addition, we also give the environment details to systemd so that it's aware of our existing X session.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Don't enable or start the service file yet. We will let our timer handle that part.
texts.text: Don't enable or start the service file yet. We will let our timer handle that part.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Setting a timer
texts.text: Setting a timer

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Systemd's concept of  timers  is pretty detailed. You have plenty of control over how and when you want a particular service to run. We need a simple calendar-based timer (much like cron) that will start up our service from the previous step.
texts.text: Systemd's concept of  timers  is pretty detailed. You have plenty of control over how and when you want a particular service to run. We need a simple calendar-based timer (much like cron) that will start up our service from the previous step.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Drop this into
texts.text: Drop this into

texts.label: code
texts.orig: ~/.config/systemd/user/gnome-background-change.timer
texts.text: ~/.config/systemd/user/gnome-background-change.timer

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
[Unit]
Description=Rotate GNOME wallpaper timer

[Timer]
OnCalendar=*:0/5
Persistent=true
Unit=gnome-background-change.service

[Install]
WantedBy=gnome-background-change.service
texts.text:
[Unit]
Description=Rotate GNOME wallpaper timer

[Timer]
OnCalendar=*:0/5
Persistent=true
Unit=gnome-background-change.service

[Install]
WantedBy=gnome-background-change.service

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: We're telling systemd that we want this timer to run every five minutes and we want to start our service unit file from the previous step. The
texts.text: We're telling systemd that we want this timer to run every five minutes and we want to start our service unit file from the previous step. The

texts.label: code
texts.orig: Persistent
texts.text: Persistent

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: line tells systemd that we want this unit file run if the last run was missed. For example, if you log in at 7:02AM, we don't want to wait until 7:05AM to rotate the background. We can rotate it immediately after login.
texts.text: line tells systemd that we want this unit file run if the last run was missed. For example, if you log in at 7:02AM, we don't want to wait until 7:05AM to rotate the background. We can rotate it immediately after login.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you'd like a different interval, be sure to review systemd's  time syntax  for the
texts.text: If you'd like a different interval, be sure to review systemd's  time syntax  for the

texts.label: code
texts.orig: OnCalendar
texts.text: OnCalendar

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: line. It's a little quirky if you're used to working with crontabs but it's very powerful once you understand it.
texts.text: line. It's a little quirky if you're used to working with crontabs but it's very powerful once you understand it.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Now we can enable and start the timer:
texts.text: Now we can enable and start the timer:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
systemctl --user enable gnome-background-change.timer
systemctl --user start gnome-background-change.timer
texts.text:
systemctl --user enable gnome-background-change.timer
systemctl --user start gnome-background-change.timer

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Checking our work
texts.text: Checking our work

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You can use systemctl to query the timer we just activated:
texts.text: You can use systemctl to query the timer we just activated:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ systemctl --user list-timers
NEXT                         LEFT          LAST                         PASSED  UNIT                          ACTIVATES
Wed 2015-02-11 08:15:00 CST  3min 53s left Wed 2015-02-11 08:10:49 CST  16s ago gnome-background-change.timer gnome-background-change.service
texts.text:
$ systemctl --user list-timers
NEXT                         LEFT          LAST                         PASSED  UNIT                          ACTIVATES
Wed 2015-02-11 08:15:00 CST  3min 53s left Wed 2015-02-11 08:10:49 CST  16s ago gnome-background-change.timer gnome-background-change.service

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: In my case, this shows that the background rotation service last ran 16 seconds ago. It will run again in just under four minutes. If you find that the service runs but your wallpaper doesn't change, try running
texts.text: In my case, this shows that the background rotation service last ran 16 seconds ago. It will run again in just under four minutes. If you find that the service runs but your wallpaper doesn't change, try running

texts.label: code
texts.orig: journalctl -xe
texts.text: journalctl -xe

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: to see if your service is throwing any errors.
texts.text: to see if your service is throwing any errors.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Additional reading
texts.text: Additional reading

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This is just the tip of the iceberg of what systemd can do with user unit files and timers. the Arch Linux wiki has some awesome documentation about  user unit files  and  timers . Check out the other timers that already exist on your system for more ideas.
texts.text: This is just the tip of the iceberg of what systemd can do with user unit files and timers. the Arch Linux wiki has some awesome documentation about  user unit files  and  timers . Check out the other timers that already exist on your system for more ideas.
